moves.1. e4 a6: Unusual!  The sort of move played by my young grandson but I didn't let that put me off.  There are lots of sensible follow-ups...
moves.2. d4 e6 3. Nf3 b5: Black's moves conspire to hem my lsb in before it's even peeped out of the vestry.
moves.4. Bd3 Bb7 5. Bg5: I reasoned that my Nb1 would probably get harassed if it moved to c3, so I planned moving it to d2 but didn't want to hem in my dsb.  This B has nothing much to bite on yet as the attack on the Q is easily foiled but would pin a N blocking the attack on the Q and could swap with a B doing the same.  If Black blocked with ...f6, that would weaken his kingside.  If Black left the B alone, it would be nicely placed.
moves.5... Ne7 6. Nbd2 h6 7. Bh4 d6 8. Qe2: Hoping to open lines towards Black's K and in the meantime keeping my castling options flexible.
moves.8... Qd7: Black unpins his N at the cost of depriving his Nb8 of its safest square.
moves.9. O-O: Memories of my first game of the season (my last annotation) persuaded me against castling long.
moves.9... f5: This seemed an intemperate response with his K still stuck in the centre.  I think he was looking to trap my dsb.
moves.10. exf5 exf5 11. Rfe1: ! The battery on the e-file dominates the game for the next 10 moves.
moves.11... g5 12. Bxg5: I didn't have much choice here but saw it as an opportunity to develop an attack on his K
moves.12... hxg5 13. Nxg5 Nbc6: Black prepares to castle long but ...
moves.14. Ne6: !  This N virtually seals Black's fate as he cannot castle now without budging it, which is very difficult...
moves.14... Nb4: I hadn't expected that but it wasn't very frightening.  I saw another opportunity to open a file for a rook.
moves.15. Nf3 Nxd3: Black has just played 3 consecutive moves to swap this N off and open a file for my other rook.
moves.16. cxd3: I wasn't worried about doubling my extra pawns in view of the advantages that outweighed this minor (in this position) disadvantage .
moves.16... Kf7 17. Rac1: This prevents ...Qc6, attacking g2 through my Nf3, and attacks c7, virtually forcing Black's reply.
moves.17... Rc8 18. Nfg5+: Thanks to the previous move, this N can safely join the attack.
moves.18... Kf6 19. Nxf8: It may seem odd to swap off this dominant N for a B that hasn't moved but I needed to operate on the Black squares to make progress and I had another N ready to land on e6.
moves.19... Rcxf8 20. Ne6: Only after I played this did I spot that Black could try 20. .. Rfg8!?, attacking g2 while leaving the other rook to dominate the h-file, which I was hoping eventually to use for my Q.
moves.20... Rfc8: Inwardly I breathed a sigh of relief to know that I didn't have to worry seriously about defence after all.
moves.21. Qe3: ! I loved this move and for the first time my opponent really sank into thought.  Up to now, I had used about 10 minutes more than him.  Over the next few moves I developed a handy cushion.  What I loved about it was that it was a logical progression from my previous play while being far from obvious and, at first sight, like so many small Q moves, seemingly innocuous.  The more I looked into it, the better it seemed - a sort of puzzle reset move.
moves.22. Qh6+ Ng6 23. Nf4: This really drove Black to distraction ...
moves.23... Be4: In his desperation to block the e-file, Black gives up a piece to leave me two clear pawns ahead, with a crushing attack developing.
moves.24... Kf7 25. Nh5: The attack proceeds without checks, causing Black to ponder ever deeper.
moves.25... Ne7 26. Qf6+: Only my third check of the game but I'm totally dominating.
moves.26... Ke8 27. exf5: The N is pinned yet again.
moves.28. Qf7 Qxf5: With only half a minute left, Black cracks completely.
